Dispelling Those Pesky Romantic Rumors

Posted on April 22, 2014 by Christy Pastore — 4 Comments ↓

Quite frequently Romance Writers endure an onslaught of misconceptions from naysayers, internet trolls and your typical Mean Girls/Boys.  I know every genre takes their share of light ribbing to unwelcome servings of hater aid. However, since my bread and butter is contemporary romance I’d like to dispel a few of the many nonsensical myths we deal with every time we tell someone about our books, short stories and novellas.

1. You Just Write ‘Mommy Porn’.

Honestly, I don’t even know what this term, ‘Mommy Porn,’ means. So let’s look it up on our favorite search engine. Well, all that returned was a whole lot of links to sites that have videos. Videos, amateur dirty movies and clips with key words used such as: Mom Videos, Free Mom Porn, Luxury MILFs, Cheating Wives, Sexy Mom and other terms with expletives that I don’t care to print here. I refuse to share/link any of this to my blog, so you can look it up on your own.

Urban Dictionary defines ‘Mommy Porn’ as: A sub-genre of erotica that grew out of the mainstream success of E.L. James’ erotic novel “Fifty Shades of Grey.” Characterized by its perceived audience and elegant description of female sexual domination, Mommy Porn first gained popularity with moms over thirty years old before it quickly spread to a worldwide audience.The characteristics that define Mommy Porn are: Its focus on female sexual fantasy; The introduction of an innocent female protagonist to an unimagined world of sex; A controlling, alpha male love interest; and its detailed description of sex without using graphic words.

‘Mommy Porn’ is  sub-genre of Erotica, (per the above findings ) not Contemporary Romance which is a sub-genre of Romance. Let me take this a step further, I’m going to say that the word ‘Mommy Porn’  is an implied stereotype or attitude linked to a particular group of readers. Anyway, bottom line, this term needs to go away, and why do we have a problem with women wanting to read Erotica? It’s a completely healthy form of sexual expression.  Who cares? Honestly, why is this is a big deal? The books are works of fiction unless otherwise stated. Grab your flirty dirty read and enjoy. Don’t let someone smut shame you.

2. You Write It, So You Must Live It.

This is my favorite myth. Again, these books are works of fiction unless otherwise stated.  I’m not going to give in to the “I practice what I preach” mindset, or allow you any access into my own sex life. And frankly, I don’t care about yours. I hope your sex life is everything you want it to be, and if it’s not–change it up! I had a friend who endlessly wanted to gab to me about her sex life with her husband (in graphic detail) like we were two twenty-something, single gals newly exploring our way through the prime of our sexual life. It was all very SATC. It made for great television, but those scenarios aren’t really conducive in real life. No, just please, no. I don’t want to hear about the drunken sex you had with your husband last Friday night. My sex life is just that, MY sex life with my husband. It is not for you to hear about. If you have a BFF or a sister that you chat about your sex life with, that is awesome. It’s always nice to have a close relationship with a female friend. I can tell you most of us will never tell you our bedroom secrets. That would put us into an entirely different career.

3. Your Books Are All Sex and No Substance.

Really? Even ‘Fifty Shades of Grey’ had a plot, and at the end of the day it was about two people who found a deep, passionate love, and it worked for them. I have yet to encounter a contemporary romance novel that doesn’t have a plot or dramatic substance in some manner.  I can count the total number of sex scenes in my book, “Fifteen Weekends” on two hands. Sex is a part of life, and when you’re writing romance it’s a part of the story. A writer friend of mine, Andrea Joan says: “We are not oversexed nymphos, just because we like the genre. And there are STORIES in these books. Its NOT just sex.” I completely agree with this statement. Why would anyone want to just read chapter after chapter of pure sex? Oh, wait a minute…that is what a porn is for, talk about NO substance. At least we give stories that provoke feelings and emotions, allowing you to care about the characters and their story. With that being said, I am not anti-porno.

4. Why Are You A Pervert?

Excuse me?  Or should I say, Ex-squeeze me? {Just Kidding} Just because I buy and read Contemporary Romance and Erotica novels does not make me a pervert. There ‘s a common theme between romance/erotic writers: We don’t have dirty minds, we just have sexy imaginations. (Thank you Jenn). It is one thing to perform a sex act, it’s quite another to write it so that a reader will enjoy it. Romance and Erotica Authors are often accused of sitting with their hands up their skirts, shoved between their thighs or spread wide diddling themselves writing sex scenes. Personally, I must have total concentration when I write, furthermore I need two hands to type. My writing doesn’t get me all hot and bothered, it’s there for the readers’ enjoyment. When we create our characters, they are sort of like our children. We watch them grow and develop, nurturing their every emotion. Now, with that in mind, I do read my finished work and say, “Damn, that scene was sexy as hell.” It’s hard not to admire one’s work.

There you have it, four myths that we, as Romance Writer’s deal with each and everyday. Do you feel differently about Contemporary Romance now?  What book are you currently reading? Indulge me.
